main.title: asdf jkl;
main.guide:
All the eight fingers except the thumbs should be placed on the home row. This is done by placing the left forefinger on F and the right forefinger on J. Place the remaining fingers on the keys beside them in a natural manner. So, the left little finger would be on A and the right little finger would be on the ; (semicolon) key. Use the right little finger to remove an error with ← key.

To type any key, press the key with the finger over it. Use one of the thumbs to press the space bar. Keep your eyes on the screen as you type. Do not look at the keyboard.

Proceed to the next lesson only when you can type with 2% or less errors and atleast 20 words/minute (WPM). Accuracy is more important than speed for a beginner.

Note:

With one hour practice every day, you can master typing in two weeks(up to Unit 15)! One more week for mastering numbers(up to Unit 21). The rest is for full keyboard mastery.

As you practice, you'll encounter terms related to Bible scriptures and Ignatian spirituality to inspire your learning.

main.guide: Use the left little finger to type Z and the right little finger to type the slash (/). Return gently to the home row after each reach. These drills channel zeal toward praise/peace rather than frenzy, echoing the Exercises’ patient focus.

subunits.Sentences: Zeal is purified by praise, not by frenzy: zero the noise and choose peace. In Nazareth and Zion alike, the breeze carries psalms; Zacchaeus, dazzled, descends and gives back with zest. Freeze rash buzz; analyze, then evangelize; cross the zigzag path with patient focus. With the Spiritual Exercises, zeal becomes breezy, precise—praise/peace/zeal aligned; lips zip when love listens, and the soul blazes quietly.

main.guide:
Use the right little finger to type the apostrophe ('). Strike lightly and return to ';' on the home row. In this unit we practice contractions and possessives—God's love, Jesus's mercy, Ignatius's notes—so your pinky gains control on frequent, faith-themed words.

Tip: Prefer simple, consistent styles (e.g., Jesus's, Ignatius's; saints' for plurals). Keep eyes on the screen; accuracy before speed.

main.title: Shift
main.guide:
Press Shift with the hand opposite the letter: Right Shift for left-hand letters, Left Shift for right-hand letters. Use a gentle tap, then return to home row. We will capitalize Ignatian and Catholic names (Ignatius, Xavier, Society of Jesus) while you train precise timing on the Shift key.

Tip: Keep wrists level and shoulders relaxed; aim for clean capitals without grip or hesitation.

main.title: Practice Passages
main.guide: Type these practice passages slowly and accurately. Each passage paraphrases trusted Ignatian and Catholic sources so that your learning joins skill with substance. Where a text is traditionally prayed (e.g., Anima Christi, Suscipe), we render it in paraphrase for typing. Breathe, keep posture aligned, and let accuracy lead speed.

subunits.Principle and Foundation: We are created to praise, reverence, and serve God, and by this path to order our lives in freedom. All created things are gifts offered so that we might seek the Giver; we use them insofar as they help, set them aside when they hinder, and hold indifference toward health or sickness, riches or poverty, honor or dishonor. In this foundation we discover purpose: choose what leads to deeper love, and let lesser loves be rightly placed. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row.
subunits.Anima Christi: Soul of Christ, sanctify my desires; Body of Christ, strengthen my service; Blood of Christ, enliven my courage; Water from Christ's side, wash my memory. Within your wounds hide me; let no evil spirit divide me. Call me to your presence and bid me remain until praise becomes my habit and mercy my reflex. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row.
subunits.Suscipe: Take, Lord, receive my liberty, memory, understanding, and will—every plan and preference I clutch. All is from you and for you; I return it, asking only for love and grace. If you grant these, I have enough; if you lead otherwise, I still belong to you, and that belonging is peace. Let accuracy lead; speed will follow in due time.
subunits.Examen Prayer: Ask for light; give thanks; review the day; face faults with truth; look ahead with hope. This quiet examen welcomes God's presence into ordinary hours: a conversation about desires, choices, consolations, and desolations. Name patterns honestly and choose tomorrow's next faithful step. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.John 3:16: God so loved the world that love moved first: not to condemn but to give life. The Beloved is offered, and whoever trusts receives a share in that life—here and forever. The cross discloses the measure of mercy; faith opens the heart to light, so fear gives way to freedom. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row.
subunits.Romans 12:12: Be joyful in hope, patient in affliction, faithful in prayer: a compact rule for disciples under pressure. Rejoice not in easy outcomes but in God's nearness; endure trials without bitterness; keep a steady rhythm of intercession for others. Stay calm; make every keystroke intentional.
subunits.Hebrews 11:1: Faith is confidence in what we hope for and conviction about what we do not see. It steadies the soul to act in love before evidence appears, trusting the unseen fidelity of God who cannot lie. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.1 Corinthians 13: Without love, eloquence and knowledge ring hollow. Love is patient and kind; it does not envy or boast; it bears and believes and hopes and endures. Prophecies pass; love remains. In the mirror of Christ we mature, laying down pride and choosing the better way. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row. Stay calm; make every keystroke intentional.
subunits.Psalm 23: The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want. He makes me lie down in green pastures and leads me beside still waters. Even in the valley I fear no evil, for you are with me; your rod and staff comfort and guide me toward a table of mercy. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.Catechism 1: God, infinitely perfect and blessed in himself, freely created man to share his own blessed life. He gathers us into one family in the Church and, through revelation and grace, invites every heart to seek, know, and love him. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row.
subunits.Catechism 27: The desire for God is written in the human heart because we are created by God and for God. We restlessly search until we rest in him; he never ceases to draw us, and our dignity blooms in this living relationship. Stay calm; make every keystroke intentional.
subunits.Catechism 293: Creation springs from the Father's glory and tends toward that same glory. Not from necessity or chance but from love, God calls beings into existence so that, sharing goodness, they may reflect and praise the Giver. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.Ignatius Autobiography: Wounded at Pamplona, Ignatius began a pilgrimage from vanity to magnanimity. In Loyola and Manresa he learned to read interior motions, to sift spirits, and to desire the greater good, until his heart was set on helping souls for the glory of God. Let accuracy lead; speed will follow in due time.
subunits.Letters of Ignatius: Ignatius writes as a patient coach: encourage the desolate, moderate the consoled, prefer the common good to private impulse. He counsels obedience with intelligence, friendship rooted in Christ, and decisions made in freedom for mission. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.Constitutions of Jesuits: The Constitutions order a body for mission: candidates tried in prayer and service; studies for competence; obedience to send and sustain; community life to support zeal; governance to distribute labor for the greater glory of God. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row.
subunits.Life of Francis Xavier: Friend of Ignatius and tireless missionary, Francis Xavier crossed seas toward India and Japan, preaching Christ with bold simplicity, learning languages, and forming communities that endured beyond his own brief years. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.General Congregations: General Congregations gather representatives to elect a Superior General, confirm mission, and discern directions for the Society. Rooted in prayer, they read the times and renew availability for the Church's needs. Practice steadily; pause, review, proceed with peace.
subunits.Ratio Studiorum: The Ratio Studiorum standardized Jesuit education in 1599, organizing studies in grammar, humanities, philosophy, and theology with careful pedagogy. It sought excellence joined to virtue, uniting intellectual rigor with formation for service. Breathe, type, and keep your eyes on the line.
subunits.Jesuit Vows: Jesuits profess poverty, chastity, and obedience for the sake of intimate union with Christ and universal mission; many priests also make a special vow of obedience regarding missions entrusted by the Pope, a pledge of availability for the Church. Practice steadily; pause, review, proceed with peace.
subunits.Rules for Discernment: Notice consolation that enlarges faith, hope, and love; notice desolation that narrows the heart. In consolation, plan humbly; in desolation, hold steady, resist false urgencies, and recall God's past fidelity while asking for help. Keep posture tall; return fingers to home row.

main.title: Number Passages
main.guide: Type the number passages with the correct fingers as practiced in earlier units. Keep the rhythm even, keep the digit load high, and keep text minimal. Each mini-passage pairs real Ignatian/Catholic anchors with dense number strings. Accuracy first; speed grows from steadiness. Some sequences are intentionally laddered or mirrored to build fluidity. Historical anchors reflect reputable sources; where creative sequences appear, they are clearly drills. Breathe, sit tall, and return to home row after every reach. This unit is designed to be mostly numerals with sparse words so your fingers work the number row thoroughly. For variety and stamina, some anchors repeat. Use the runs creatively for practice (note: some elements are fictionalized for typing flow).

subunits.Ignatius Birth and Death: Ignatius of Loyola: 1491→1556. Key waypoints for practice—1521 (Pamplona), 1522 (Montserrat/Manresa), 1534 (Montmartre vows), 1540 (papal approval), 1548 (Exercises). Type the digits in calm series: 1491 1521 1522 1534 1540 1548 1556; then mirror: 1556 1548 1540 1534 1522 1521 1491. Numbers anchor memory; drills shape fluency—pace 14|91, 15|21, 15|56. 1491 1540 1548 1556 1506 1552 1622
subunits.Jesuit Founding: Founding timeline for focused digits: 1534 (Paris vows, 7 companions), 1540 (Regimini militantis Ecclesiae), 1541 (first vows in Rome), 1551 (Roman College), 1556 (Ignatius dies). Ladder drills: 1534→1540→1541→1551→1556; repeat 15-34, 15-40, 15-41, 15-51, 15-56; then reverse the run for retention. 1491 1540 1548 1556 1506 1552 1622
subunits.Francis Xavier: Francis Xavier: 1506-1552; set drills: 1506 1541 1542 1549 1552. Voyage markers—Goa (1542), Japan (1549), Sancian/Shangchuan (1552). Type forward 1506→1552, then interleave: 1541, 1542, 1549. Keep digits dense; keep words few; keep rhythm even. 1491 1540 1548 1556 1506 1552 1622
subunits.Bible Books and Chapters: Catholic canon: 73 books (46 OT, 27 NT). Sample anchors to type: Gen 1, Ex 20, Ps 23, Is 40, Mt 5, Lk 15, Jn 3, Acts 2, Rom 8, 1 Cor 13, Rev 22. Practice strings: 73|46|27; 1|20|23|40|5|15|3|2|8|13|22. 1491 1540 1548 1556 1506 1552 1622
subunits.Catechism Sections: Catechism paragraphs: 2865 total; 4 parts; examples to drill—CCC 1, 27, 1831, 2559, 2777-2865. Type ladders: 27→127→227→…; then 1831→1832→1837; finish with 2777→2865. 1491 1540 1548 1556 1506 1552 1622

main.guide: Use the left fingers, i.e littlefinger to type ! ring-finger to type @ middle-finger to type #, and the index-finger to type $. These are left-hand symbols on the number row. Strike lightly, breathe, and return to the home row. Keep the density of symbols high so the left hand works. Build control before speed; accuracy grows flow; flow sustains stamina. This unit focuses on combinations that appear in faith-related prompts, projects, and labels, but the intent is symbol fluency. Practice in context of spiritual messages.

subunits.Words: #AMDG! @Ignatius #Examen! $alms #mercy $justice @mission #Magis! !psalm73 #Jn3_16 $Mt5 @Lk15 #Acts2 $Rom8 @1Cor13 #Ps27 !pray #serve $give @go #console $comfort @welcome #hope! !Offer: $10 #works_of_mercy @today; #fast $almsgiving @prayer !call #respond $repeat @practice #focus $balance @breath #steady! !@#$
subunits.Sentences: #Give $alms! #Guard $time! @Pray, then #act—AMDG! !Joy rises; #grace grows; $costs counted; @call accepted. We tag prompts: #faith #hope #charity; we budget: $1 $3 $5 $8; we ping friends @campus, @parish, @service; we rally with #Magis! Symbols say it short: ! urgency, @ mention, # topic, $ value; type in runs: !@#$ !@#$ !@#$; breathe; repeat. !@#$
subunits.Test: !@#$ x 10; #AMDG! @mission #mercy $justice; !alert @team #task $budget; !start @now #today $10; !@ !@@ !@@@ # ## ### $ $$ $$$; !@#$→@#$!→#!$@→$@#!; repeat 3x, pause, then !@#$ 10x clean. !@#$

main.guide: Use the right-hand number row for & * ( ). Press Shift with the opposite hand to the symbol you type, then return to home row. Keep shoulders low and eyes up; favor accuracy over speed. We’ll weave short Ignatian anchors (e.g., AMDG) while keeping symbol density high.

subunits.Words: faith & works; mercy & justice; pray & serve; bread & blankets; love *(costly)*, hope *(steady)*; AMDG & mission (go & give); truth & tenderness; neighbor & need; ora & labora (pray & work); vow & vow-renewal; body & soul (one & whole).
subunits.Sentences: Grace & grit belong together: pray & serve, listen & act, give & go. Use opposite-hand Shift (*) and keep wrists level; type (&) as a link of love, and bracket distractions ( ) while you breathe. The goal isn’t noise but skill: strings like &*() &*() steady the right hand, while words stay light. Practice with kindness (& patience) and end with a quiet amen ( ).

main.guide: All eight left/right number-row symbols in one place: ! @ # $ & * ( ). Tap with the proper finger, use the opposite-hand Shift, strike lightly, and reset to home row. We’ll tag AMDG prompts, mission notes, and budgets to make drills memorable while keeping symbol load high.

subunits.Words: #AMDG! @Ignatius #Examen! $alms @mission #Magis! pray (&) serve (*); love (costly) + grace (free); tag @parish #service $budget; note: ‘!’ urgency, ‘@’ mention, ‘#’ topic, ‘$’ value, ‘&’ join, ‘*’ multiply, ‘( )’ hold, ‘+’ add.
subunits.Sentences: Signal cleanly: ! urgency, @ address, # topic, $ value, & link, * multiply, ( ) contain, + add. Example: #AMDG!—order work to God’s glory; @team, update #budget: $10+$5 for alms; serve (&) study; pray (*) practice; write (goals) and add + review. Type !@#$&*() in runs; breathe; return to home row.

main.guide: US QWERTY focus on backtick/tilde, minus/underscore, equals/plus, percent, caret, and underscore joins. Use opposite-hand Shift for all shifted symbols. On most courses: ` and ~ with the left little finger; -/_ and =/+ with the right little finger; % on 5 with the left index; ^ on 6 usually with the right index (some curricula teach left index). Keep wrists level and return to home row after each reach.

subunits.Words: `AMDG` ~mission ^prayer _examen +charity -ego =service %mercy ratio_studiorum~1599 ; manresa^1522 ; montmartre=1534 ; pamplona-1521 ; canonization=1622 ; use `_` to join, `-` to separate, `=` to assign, `~` to approximate, `^` to mark superscripts, `%` for shares, `+` to add. practice: `-=~%^_+` `-=~%^_+` `-=~%^_+` ; compose: love+justice=service ; pride-ego=freedom~humility ; hope^2 + mercy^2 ~= joy^2 ;  repeat:`-=~%^_+` add:+ plus:+ join:_ sep:- approx:~ assign:= share:% raise:^ `faith` `hope` `love` ;

main.title: Chars passages
main.guide: Intensive symbol practice: focus on ! @ # $ & * ( ) and ` - = ~ % ^ _ +. Keep shoulders down, wrists level, eyes on text; tap lightly and use opposite-hand Shift, then return to home row. Short anchors like #AMDG (Jesuit motto) and “Examen” keep meaning present while you drill primarily symbols.

subunits.Passage 01: #AMDG !@#$ &*() `-=~%^_+ ; pray(quietly)*serve(bravely); @team #works_of_mercy $10+$5+$3 for alms; review: examen~daily -> ask+thank+review+repent+resolve; loop: !@#$ !@#$ &*() &*() `-=~%^_+ `-=~%^_+ ; breathe, reset, continue.
subunits.Passage 02: @mission #Magis !start now: $0+$1+$2+$3 budget; link love&justice -> service(+); trim pride-ego=0; keep hope^2+mercy^2~=joy^2; drill: `-`=`-=`, then `-=~` -> `-=~%^` -> `-=~%^_+`; repeat !@#$ &*() cleanly.
subunits.Passage 03: #examen @evening: ask+thanks+review+repent+resolve; type runs: !@ !@@ !@@@ ### $$$ &&& *** ((())) ; weave `~~~` --- === ___ ++++ %% ^^ __ ++ ; finish with !@#$&*() `-=~%^_+.
subunits.Passage 04: signal: ! urgency, @ address, # topic, $ value, & join, * multiply, ( ) hold, ~ approx, ^ raise, _ joiner, - minus, = assign, + add; now drill: !@#$→!@#$&→!@#$&*→!@#$&*()→`-=~%^_+ ; repeat twice, eyes up.

subunits.Passage 07: @campus ping; #budget: $12+$15+$22; quick prayer(examen): ask+thank+review+repent+resolve; practice block: `~~~` ___ --- === ; stack: %%^^ ^^%% ; cycle: !@#$ &*() `-=~%^_+ ; soft touch, steady tempo.
subunits.Passage 08: labels: #Gospel #Examen #AMDG; math-note: hope^3~joy^3 when love+mercy>ego; drill: !@ !@# !@#$ !@#$& !@#$&* !@#$&*() ; splice with `-` `_` `=` `+` ; rest, repeat, return home.

main.title: Fluidity practice
main.guide: Type these fluidity passages using every skill from Units 1–25: steady letters, dense numbers, and confident symbols. Keep wrists level, use opposite-hand Shift, and return to home row after each reach. These lines weave Ignatian anchors—A.M.D.G., Examen steps, and rules for discernment—into mixed drills so accuracy stays first, rhythm follows, and speed grows naturally.

subunits.Ignatius Journey: Pamplona (1521) breaks pride; Montserrat (1522) bends plans; Manresa (1522) births the Examen; Paris (1534) vows; Rome (1540) sends. I type and travel: walk→watch→write; tags: #AMDG, @companions; budget: $1+$3+$5+$8; maps: 1491→1556; prayer: ask+thank+review+repent+resolve; ladder: !@ → !@# → !@#$ → !@#$&*(); braid with `-=~%^_+` and steady letters—free hands, firm hope, full heart. Order work to God’s glory—A.M.D.G.—return to home row.
subunits.Bible Hope: Bible hope speaks in numbers and names: Jn 3:16, Lk 15:4–7, Mt 5:3–12, Ps 23, Rom 8. I type: 3:16→5:3→23→8; I breathe; I believe. Shepherd words steady steps: walk–rest–restore; symbols say it short—! urgency, @ address, # topic, $ gift; I tag #faith #hope #charity and add $1+$3+$5+$8; I weave `-=~%^_+` between verses and write the examen nightly: ask+thank+review+repent+resolve.
subunits.Jesuit Scientists: Jesuit scientists: Clavius 1538–1612 (calendar math); Kircher 1602–1680 (museums & magnets); Boscovich 1711–1787 (forces); Secchi 1818–1878 (spectra). I type ladders: 1538→1612→1602→1680→1711→1787→1818→1878; tags: #ratio #observatory; budget line: $1+$3+$5+$8 for lenses; equations: hope^2+reason^2~=service^2; drill: !@#$&*() woven with `-=~%^_+`; aim calm speed, clean errors, clear eyes.
subunits.Catechism Creation: Catechism: CCC 1, 27, 293; creation ex nihilo, ordered to glory; human hearts made for God, restless until they rest in him. Digits anchor thought: 6 days, 7th rest; I type: 1→27→293, then 6→7; symbols summarize—= assign, - subtract, + add, ~ approximate, ^ raise, ( ) hold; full run: !@#$&*() braided with `-=~%^_+`; return to home row—AMDG.
subunits.Discernment Rules: Discernment: SE 313–327 name rules for the first set; 328–336 the second. In desolation, never change (rule 5); in consolation, plan humbly; check the source, course, and fruit. I drill flows: ask+thank+review+repent+resolve; then symbols: !@#$&*() and `-=~%^_+`; I tag #consolation #desolation, add $1+$3+$5+$8, and end with #AMDG.
